https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/95873/ : SUCCESS
Just a few questions, overall this looks good.

How does [net,]eid map to <device index>?
Is this <device index> different than that used for --index?
Are you planning on providing an example invocation?

When we're using a NCSI-over-MCTP connection, there is likely no corresponding network device. So, we would only specify either `--index` (for a "local" Linux network device) or `--mctp` (for a device that is reachable over MCTP).

Good idea on adding an example invocation, I'll update the help text to add one.
Done

Is there a reason these need to be shared_ptr?
These appear to be unique_ptr in nature from what I can tell.

The `interface` pointer may be copied into the `nl` pointer (but only in the case of a netlink-based connection, as there are facilities that are only available over netlink). So, we need the `shared_ptr` refcounting to determine when we're safe to delete the underlying interface.

Currently, those two vars do have the same scope, so this is mostly academic, but I'd say that using a `shared_ptr` is likely safer against future changes.
Done

Is there any benefit gained by changing the preceding three lines to constexpr?
These are invariant, and known at compile time.
Do you have a purpose in this form of definition?
No particular puropose for `const` over `constexpr`, it's just my C background showing :) I'll change to `constexpr`.
Done
LGTM

I disagree with the direction of this whole series, and the premise that just because we chose the name ncsi_util it should combine the independent requirements for forming ncsi packets to inject into an AF_MCTP socket with its prior function of administrating the kernel NC-SI stack via netlink.   

This series is adding untreated-to-netlink to ncsi_netlink_main.cpp and not providing proper exclusion of mutually conflicting options.

The kernel currently only allows injection of OEM commands from userspace and with good reason to avoid confusing the kernel NC-SI implementation.  There are strict rules about sending one outstanding NC-SI packet per package and an 8-bit sequence number for replay detection that will cause collisions with multiple collisions.  

I propose we add a NL message that provides start transfer and additional data blocks and let the kernel form the data packets.  In addition it should store the AEN frame advertising availability of the dump for retrevial (section 8.5.8).

> I disagree with the direction of this whole series, and the premise that just because we chose the name ncsi_util it should combine the independent requirements for forming ncsi packets to inject into an AF_MCTP socket with its prior function of administrating the kernel NC-SI stack via netlink.

The utility is _already_ used for more than just administering the kernel NC-SI stack, given the usage for OEM command interactions with the NIC.

> The kernel currently only allows injection of OEM commands from userspace

That's not correct - any command can be sent from userspace via the netlink channel.

> and with good reason to avoid confusing the kernel NC-SI implementation.

There is absolutely no conflict between a MCTP channel and the in-kernel NCSI stack, so no chance of this "confusion".

This series provides a *new* transport for the NCSI messages, in which case the kernel has zero interaction with the NCSI state on those devices (because it is performing zero communication with those NICs; there is no RMII connection, otherwise we would be using it for the transport!)

> There are strict rules about sending one outstanding NC-SI packet per package and an 8-bit sequence number for replay detection that will cause collisions with multiple collisions.

Sure, but we're not conflicting here. The kernel is not performing any NCSI control with the devices we're targeting over MCTP.

discord discussion with @jk asking for a separate utility with the new focus of creating ncsi packets vs control of the kernel ncsi through netlink 
https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/778790638563885086/1305769802865840148
Interface Index
That's already present in the code. I can rework to "index", but that would be a separate change.

mctp should not be ignored when ifIndex is specified

Instead check that only one is specified
And one or the other is required so adjust the usage
Sure, I'll add a check to ensure that only one is specified.
Done
